title: Kerala to hand over ivory, deer horns to Army establishments
summary:
#### Summary:

The Kerala Government has granted a request from two Indian Army establishments to obtain elephant tusks and deer horns for safekeeping. The Pangode Military Station and Grenadiers RC will receive 10 pairs each of elephant tusks, deer horns, and mounts/horns, while the Second Battalion of Madras Regiment will receive three pairs each of elephant tusks and deer antlers. The trophies will be kept under the safe custody of the Army establishments and are not to be displayed, modified, or transferred. This request comes at a time when the Union Ministry of Environment, Forest and Climate Change has proposed the incineration of wildlife trophies and discouraged their display [[1]](https://www.thehindu.com/news/cities/Kochi/army-establishments-seek-ivory-for-safe-custody-from-kerala/article67726953.ece).

title: Seven flights diverted to Hyderabad airport as major Indian cities battle heavy fog
summary:
#### Summary:

Persistent fog across the nation disrupted air travel on Monday, leading to the diversion, delay, or cancellation of numerous flights due to poor visibility and unfavorable weather conditions. Hyderabad's Rajiv Gandhi International Airport (RGIA) emerged as a diversion hub for several airlines. As of Monday morning, seven flights, including four international ones, were diverted to Hyderabad. The diversions included four flights from Kolkata's Netaji Subhas Chandra International Airport, two from Chennai International Airport, and one from Delhi's Indira Gandhi International Airport [[1]](https://www.thehindu.com/news/national/telangana/seven-flights-diverted-to-hyderabad-airport-as-major-indian-cities-battle-heavy-fog/article67742644.ece).

#### Flight Diversions:

Several flights were diverted to Hyderabad's Rajiv Gandhi International Airport due to the persistent fog and unfavorable weather conditions. The flights rerouted from Kolkata included AIX Connect's I5 992 and I5 558 bound from Bengaluru's Kempegowda International Airport, Vistara Air's UK 727 from Delhi, and SpiceJet's SG 517 from Bengaluru. Additionally, IndiGo's flight 6E 1002 from Singapore's Changi Airport heading to Chennai was redirected to Hyderabad, and British Airways BA 035 from London's Heathrow Airport to Chennai experienced a similar fate. The sole diversion from Delhi was Egypt Air's flight MS 973 from Cairo International Airport to Delhi, which was rerouted to Hyderabad.

#### Impact on Flight Operations:

The adverse weather conditions in other cities contributed to numerous flight delays and cancellations at GMR Hyderabad International Airport. The disruptions caused flight delays and diversions, with a total of 37 flights being canceled and numerous others experiencing delays and diversions due to the unfavorable conditions. IndiGo airlines had the highest number of cancellations, with 30 flights affected. Other airlines, including Air India, Air Asia, Alliance Air, and SpiceJet, also had flights canceled or delayed. The disrupted routes primarily included flights to and from Chennai [[7]](https://www.thehindu.com/news/national/telangana/cyclone-michaung-causes-flight-disruptions-at-hyderabad-airport/article67603629.ece).

#### Compensation for Flight Disruptions:

Passengers may be entitled to compensation or ticket reimbursement in the event of flight delays, cancellations, or overbooking. However, compensation for flight disruptions due to bad weather is subject to certain conditions. Under EU Regulation 261, passengers can usually claim compensation for bad weather-related flight disruptions if the flight took off from a European airport or was operated by a European airline and landed in the European Union [[3]](https://www.flightright.co.uk/your-rights/bad-weather).

#### Conclusion:

Persistent fog and unfavorable weather conditions led to the diversion, delay, and cancellation of numerous flights across the nation. Hyderabad's Rajiv Gandhi International Airport served as a diversion hub for several airlines. Passengers affected by flight disruptions due to bad weather may be eligible for compensation, subject to certain conditions.

title: 65 lakh pilgrims visit Ganga Sagar Mela says W.B. govt
summary:
#### Summary:

Approximately 6.5 million pilgrims from across the country visited Sagar Island in West Bengal to take a holy dip at the confluence of the Ganga River and the Bay of Bengal during the Ganga Sagar Mela. The West Bengal government has been promoting religious tourism as a priority sector, leading to a rise in pilgrims and visitors to every religious pilgrimage in the state. The annual pilgrimage started on January 8 and concluded on January 17, with the auspicious timing for the holy dip being from 00:13 hrs on January 15 to 00:13 hrs on January 16. Elaborate security arrangements were made, including 14,000 police personnel, 1,150 closed-circuit television cameras, 12 drones, and 45 watchtowers. Pilgrims were ferried to Sagar Island through 36 vessels, 100 launches, and six barges across 22 jetties. Despite claims by the state government of providing enough arrangements and night shelters for pilgrims, some people were seen sleeping in the open on the mela grounds. The West Bengal government has demanded 'national fair' status for the Gangasagar Mela, similar to the Kumbh Mela. The projected budget for the mela this year is Rs 250 crore, and the state government stated that the center is not contributing any funds. Around 250 people have been arrested for involvement in various illegal activities, including pickpocketing. Two deaths have been reported, and six people have been airlifted to hospitals in Kolkata.

title: Maharashtra Speaker’s decision conflicts with SC ruling on factions
summary:
#### Summary of Maharashtra Speaker's Decision and SC Ruling on Factions

The Maharashtra Speaker's decision regarding the "real" Shiv Sena party conflicts with a Supreme Court judgment. The Speaker based their decision on the "legislative majority" held by the faction led by Chief Minister Eknath Shinde, claiming that they were the "real" Shiv Sena. However, a Constitution Bench of the Supreme Court, led by Chief Justice of India D.Y. Chandrachud, directed in a May 2023 judgment that the Speaker must not base their decision solely on which group possesses a majority in the Legislative Assembly. The court emphasized that the determination of the real party goes beyond numbers and includes the structure of leadership outside the legislative assembly. The court also clarified that the strength in numbers of a faction is irrelevant if the legislators are found guilty of defection by splitting the party, and they would be disqualified under the Tenth Schedule (anti-defection law) of the Constitution. The Constitution (Ninety-first Amendment) Act, 2003 deleted the provision of 'split' in Paragraph 3 of the Tenth Schedule, making the defense of a split no longer available to members facing disqualification proceedings [[1]](https://www.thehindu.com/news/national/maharashtra-speakers-decision-conflicts-with-sc-ruling-on-factions/article67741107.ece).

The Supreme Court had set a deadline for the Maharashtra Speaker to decide on disqualification pleas related to the split in the NCP by January 31, 2024, emphasizing the importance of maintaining the sanctity of the Tenth Schedule. The court had also questioned the Speaker's delay in adjudicating the disqualification petitions and urged the Speaker to fulfill their responsibilities in a timely manner [[3]](https://www.thehindu.com/news/national/sc-sets-deadline-for-maharashtra-assembly-speaker-to-decide-on-disqualification-petitions/article67475881.ece) [[6]](https://www.hindustantimes.com/india-news/shiv-sena-disqualification-pleas-rahul-narwekar-eknath-shinde-mlas-supreme-court-101698651340396.html) [[7]](https://indianexpress.com/article/india/sc-sets-december-31-deadline-for-maharashtra-speaker-to-decide-on-disqualification-pleas-against-shinde-faction-9005866/).

title: Last batch of Mizoram Bru refugees permanently settled in Tripura
summary:
The Tripura government has allocated land for the rehabilitation of the last batch of Mizoram Bru refugees, who were granted permanent settlement in Tripura through a Home Ministry-initiated quadripartite agreement signed on January 16, 2020. The agreement aimed to permanently settle a total of 6,959 Bru tribe families comprising 37,136 persons in 12 different locations across four districts in Tripura.

The settlement process has now been completed with the identification and allocation of land for the final group of refugees. The 12th settlement colony has been established in Laugangsom, located in the Santirbazar subdivision in south Tripura district. This colony will accommodate 633 Bru families and will be spread over an area of 30 hectares that was previously unused. Basic amenities such as electricity, drinking water, and other civic facilities are currently being provided at the site.

In addition to land allocation, the refugees are receiving monthly rations, household items, and a stipend as per the quadripartite agreement signed by the Ministry of Home Affairs (MHA) and the governments of Tripura and Mizoram with the representatives of the Bru refugees. The MHA has allocated \u20b9661 crore for the implementation of this agreement.

It is worth noting that the Bru refugees fled ethnic tensions in Mizoram in October 1997 and have been living in sub-human conditions in tents in Tripura. The quadripartite agreement aims to provide a permanent solution to their displacement and improve their living conditions [[5]](https://www.thehindu.com/news/national/other-states/displaced-bru-tribals-from-mizoram-to-permanently-settle-in-tripura/article61643819.ece).

Overall, the Tripura government has allocated land for the final group of Mizoram Bru refugees, completing the settlement process as per the quadripartite agreement. The refugees are receiving basic amenities, monthly support, and other provisions to facilitate their permanent settlement in Tripura [[1]](https://www.thehindu.com/news/national/other-states/last-batch-of-mizoram-bru-refugees-permanently-settled-in-tripura/article67740680.ece).

title: Days after infant’s death, M.P. CM seeks suggestions to curb stray dog menace
summary:
#### Summary of the Incident

On January 10, a tragic incident occurred in Bhopal, Madhya Pradesh, where a seven-month-old boy was mauled to death by a pack of stray dogs in the Ayodhya Nagar area. The incident was captured in a viral video, showing the gruesome attack that resulted in the severing of the child's arm. The child's family, who are laborers from Guna district, held the last rites on Wednesday itself. Madhya Pradesh Chief Minister Mohan Yadav expressed grief over the incident and directed officials to provide financial assistance worth Rs 4 lakh to the bereaved family. Following this tragic event, the Chief Minister sought suggestions from the public to address the issue of stray dog attacks and prevent similar incidents in the future [[1]](https://www.indiatoday.in/india/madhya-pradesh/story/madhya-pradesh-stray-dog-attack-infant-death-chief-minister-mohan-yadav-2488554-2024-01-14).

#### Measures Taken and Ongoing Actions

In response to the incident, the Bhopal Municipal Corporation caught eight stray dogs from Ayodhya Nagar, and the Collector directed a campaign to catch such animals. Additionally, the Chief Minister directed officials to seek suggestions from the people to take appropriate measures to prevent similar incidents. The body of the child was exhumed and sent for post-mortem examination on Saturday. The Ayodhya Nagar inspector, Mahesh Nilhare, reported that the child's mother had placed him on the ground to work nearby when the pack of dogs attacked him. The police and administration were alerted to the incident after the video went viral on social media [[1]](https://www.indiatoday.in/india/madhya-pradesh/story/madhya-pradesh-stray-dog-attack-infant-death-chief-minister-mohan-yadav-2488554-2024-01-14) [[4]](https://indianexpress.com/article/india/infant-mauled-to-death-by-dogs-mp-cm-seeks-peoples-suggestions-to-prevent-such-incidents-9108815/) [[7]](https://www.telegraphindia.com/feeds/india/seven-month-old-boy-mauled-to-death-by-stray-dogs-in-madhya-pradeshs-bhopal/cid/1993503).

#### Conclusion

The tragic incident of the seven-month-old boy being mauled to death by stray dogs in Bhopal has prompted the Chief Minister to take immediate action, including providing financial assistance to the family and seeking suggestions from the public to prevent similar incidents. The local authorities have also taken steps to catch stray dogs in the area and investigate the circumstances surrounding the attack.

title: Nominations invited for first-ever 'Rashtriya Vigyan Puraskar'
summary:
#### Summary of Rashtriya Vigyan Puraskar

The government has called for nominations for the Rashtriya Vigyan Puraskar, the first-ever national science award, which aims to recognize notable and inspiring contributions made by scientists, technologists, and innovators individually or in teams across various fields of science, technology, and technology-led innovation. The awards were instituted last year after scrapping more than 300 awards given by different institutions. The Rashtriya Vigyan Puraskar is set to be one of the highest recognitions in the field of science, technology, and innovation in India [[1]](https://www.indiatoday.in/science/story/rashtriya-vigyan-puraskar-all-you-need-to-know-about-the-new-science-awards-2438688-2023-09-21).

#### Award Categories and Criteria
The awards will be given across four categories: Vigyan Ratna (VR), Vigyan Shri (VS), Vigyan Yuva: Shanti Swarup Bhatnagar (VY-SSB), and Vigyan Team (VT). A total of 56 awards will be given in thirteen domains, including physics, chemistry, biological sciences, mathematics and computer science, earth science, medicine, engineering sciences, agricultural science, environmental science, technology and innovation, atomic energy, space science and technology. The awards will not be conferred posthumously, except in "highly deserving cases" [[3]](https://currentaffairs.adda247.com/government-comes-out-with-a-new-set-of-national-awards-known-as-rashtriya-vigyan-puraskar/).

#### Eligibility and Recognition
The Rashtriya Vigyan Puraskar is open to scientists, technologists, and innovators working in various sectors, including government and private organizations. Individuals of Indian origin residing abroad who have significantly benefited Indian communities or society as a whole are also eligible for these prestigious awards. The awards aim to recognize distinguished contributions through path-breaking research, innovation, or discovery in any field of science, technology, or technology-led innovation. Gender parity is also a crucial aspect, ensuring representation from each field [[3]](https://currentaffairs.adda247.com/government-comes-out-with-a-new-set-of-national-awards-known-as-rashtriya-vigyan-puraskar/).

#### Timeline and Announcement
The last date for filing nominations is February 28, and the awards will be announced on May 11, National Technology Day. The awards will be conferred on August 23, National Space Day, to commemorate Chandrayaan-3 mission's soft landing on the moon.

#### Conclusion
The Rashtriya Vigyan Puraskar is a significant initiative by the government to recognize and encourage exceptional contributions in the field of science, technology, and innovation in India. It encompasses a wide range of scientific and technological domains and aims to honor both lifetime achievements and distinguished contributions by young scientists and teams.

title: BDL-made Akash missile can strike four aerial targets simultaneously
summary:
#### Summary:

India has achieved a significant milestone by demonstrating the capability of engaging four aerial targets simultaneously at 25 km ranges using the 'Akash' missile, marking a major achievement in the field of defense technology. The Akash missile, developed by the Defence Research and Development Organisation (DRDO) and produced by Bharat Dynamics Limited (BDL), is a medium-range mobile surface-to-air missile system with the ability to protect vulnerable areas and points from air attacks. The recent firing of the Akash missile by the Indian Air Force (IAF) showcased its capability to engage multiple targets simultaneously, further solidifying its position as a key asset in India's defense arsenal [[1]](https://www.thehindu.com/news/national/telangana/bdl-made-akash-missile-can-strike-four-aerial-targets-simultaneously/article67740668.ece).

#### Akash Missile Capabilities:
- The Akash missile system is designed to protect vulnerable areas and points from air attacks, with the ability to simultaneously engage multiple targets in group mode or autonomous mode. It also features built-in Electronic Counter-Counter Measures (ECCM) capabilities [[4]](https://www.drdo.gov.in/akash).
- The missile is capable of striking enemy aerial targets such as fighter jets, drones, cruise missiles, air-to-surface missiles, and ballistic missiles from a distance of 30 km. It can fly at a speed of up to Mach 2.5 (nearly 860 meters per second) at a maximum height of 18 km [[10]](https://economictimes.indiatimes.com/news/defence/akash-missile-all-about-indias-first-home-made-supersonic-missile/articleshow/72119996.cms).

#### Manufacturing and Development:
- The Akash missiles have been manufactured by BDL at its Kanchanbagh facility, emphasizing the focus on 'Make in India' with maximum indigenous content.
- BDL's manufacturing capability has been augmented to meet both domestic and international demands of Astra missiles, positioning it among a select few companies globally with the capability to manufacture state-of-the-art air-to-air missiles.

#### Minister's Visit and Future Outlook:
- Union Minister of State for Defence Ajay Bhatt visited BDL and DRDO establishments, where he congratulated BDL for their efforts in realizing the production of the indigenously developed missile, in line with the Centre\u2019s Atmanirbhar policy. He also emphasized the need to tap into the knowledge and infrastructure base of DRDO for the establishment of a self-reliant defense industrial ecosystem in India.
- The Minister highlighted the need for DRDO to emerge as a world leader in exporting weapon systems to other nations, emphasizing that defense encompasses not only land, sea, and skies but also space, cyber, economic, and social space.

This recent development showcases India's advancements in defense technology and its commitment to self-reliance in defense manufacturing.

title: Release water from Ramanpad to protect standing crops: Jupally
summary:
Minister for Excise and Culture Jupally Krishna Rao has instructed the irrigation authorities to release water from the Ramanpad project to protect the standing Kharif paddy crops. The Minister visited the Ramanpad project after a group of farmers from the Jurala project ayacut met him and explained the need for water for one wetting to ensure a good harvest. The water from the Jurala Left Canal-Ramanpad-Gopaldinne reservoir will serve the ayacut in several mandals, including Amarachinta, Atmakur, Madanapuram, Kothakota, Pebbair, Srirangapuram, Veepanagandla, and Chinnambavi [[1]](https://www.thehindu.com/news/national/telangana/release-water-from-ramanpad-to-protect-standing-crops-jupally/article67741133.ece).

#### Water Availability and Distribution
The Minister inquired with the irrigation officials about the availability of water to ensure one wetting for the Kharif crop and meet the drinking water needs in the coming summer season. The officials informed him that water drawn from Jurala through the Bhima Lift Irrigation Project could be given to the ayacut in Kothakota, Srirangapuram, Veepanagandla, Chinnampalli, and Pentlapalli mandals.

#### Importance of Water Resources
Water is an essential resource for the sustenance of life and the development of the economy. Therefore, the development, conservation, and management of water resources are crucial [[3]](https://jalshakti-dowr.gov.in).

In summary, Minister Jupally Krishna Rao has instructed the irrigation authorities to release water from the Ramanpad project to protect the standing Kharif paddy crops. The water will be distributed to various mandals to ensure a good harvest and meet the drinking water needs in the coming summer season [[1]](https://www.thehindu.com/news/national/telangana/release-water-from-ramanpad-to-protect-standing-crops-jupally/article67741133.ece).

title: Pottela pandelu, yedla pandelu, rangoli competitions mark Sankranti festivities in villages in Andhra Pradesh
summary:
#### Summary of Sankranti Festivities in Andhra Pradesh

The Sankranti festivities in Andhra Pradesh were marked by palpable excitement in villages, with homes adorned with spectacular rangolis and the air filled with the aroma of traditional sweets. The celebrations began with farmers lighting bhogi fires and offering prayers for good rains. Additionally, pujas were performed for tractors, bullock carts, and other agricultural equipment in the fields. Women prepared traditional sweets such as pootarekulu, ariselu, sunnundalu, and payasam to celebrate Bhogi on Day 1 of Sankranti, also known as the harvest festival. Various competitions and events, including bullock cart competitions, 'banda lagudu', 'pottela pandelu', 'yedla pandelu', kite festival, rangoli contests, and traditional dress competitions, were organized in towns and villages. The police department also organized kabaddi, kho-kho, shuttle, volleyball, and other competitions for the youth in villages in Krishna district. The festival was celebrated with great enthusiasm and participation from residents and farmers from various districts [[1]](https://www.thehindu.com/news/national/andhra-pradesh/pottela-pandelu-yedla-pandelu-rangoli-competitions-mark-sankranti-festivities-in-villages-in-andhra-pradesh/article67741496.ece).

#### Significance of Sankranti in Andhra Pradesh
Sankranti is a major festival in both the Telugu states, with Andhra Pradesh celebrating its significance more prominently. The festival is particularly significant in the coastal districts of Andhra Pradesh, where agriculture is the predominant activity. The three-day harvest festival begins with Bhogi and ends with Kanuma, with the main festival celebrated on the second day, known as Sankranti. On Bhogi, the first day of the festival, people burn all negativity by symbolically lighting a bonfire and discarding old and unused items. The festival is a time of celebration for the farming community, marked by good harvest and various traditional rituals and activities [[3]](https://www.deccanchronicle.com/nation/current-affairs/070124/when-is-bhogi-and-sankranthi-2024-date-puja-time.html).

#### Conclusion
The Sankranti festivities in Andhra Pradesh were a vibrant celebration of tradition, agriculture, and community, with a wide range of activities and competitions organized to mark the occasion. The festival holds great significance in the coastal districts of Andhra Pradesh, where agriculture plays a central role in the community's livelihood and culture.

title: Seven flights diverted to Hyderabad airport as major Indian cities battle heavy fog
summary:
#### Summary:

Persistent fog across the nation disrupted air travel on Monday, leading to the diversion, delay, or cancellation of numerous flights due to poor visibility and unfavorable weather conditions. Hyderabad's Rajiv Gandhi International Airport (RGIA) emerged as a diversion hub for several airlines. As of Monday morning, seven flights, including four international ones, were diverted to Hyderabad. The diversions included four flights from Kolkata's Netaji Subhas Chandra International Airport, two from Chennai International Airport, and one from Delhi's Indira Gandhi International Airport [[1]](https://www.thehindu.com/news/national/telangana/seven-flights-diverted-to-hyderabad-airport-as-major-indian-cities-battle-heavy-fog/article67742644.ece).

#### Flight Diversions:

Several flights were diverted to Hyderabad's Rajiv Gandhi International Airport due to the persistent fog and unfavorable weather conditions. The flights rerouted from Kolkata included AIX Connect's I5 992 and I5 558 bound from Bengaluru's Kempegowda International Airport, Vistara Air's UK 727 from Delhi, and SpiceJet's SG 517 from Bengaluru. Additionally, IndiGo's flight 6E 1002 from Singapore's Changi Airport heading to Chennai was redirected to Hyderabad, and British Airways BA 035 from London's Heathrow Airport to Chennai experienced a similar fate. The sole diversion from Delhi was Egypt Air's flight MS 973 from Cairo International Airport to Delhi, which was rerouted to Hyderabad.

#### Impact on Flight Operations:

The adverse weather conditions in other cities contributed to numerous flight delays and cancellations at GMR Hyderabad International Airport. The disruptions caused flight delays and diversions, with a total of 37 flights being canceled and numerous others experiencing delays and diversions due to the unfavorable conditions. IndiGo airlines had the highest number of cancellations, with 30 flights affected. Other airlines, including Air India, Air Asia, Alliance Air, and SpiceJet, also had flights canceled or delayed. The disrupted routes primarily included flights to and from Chennai [[7]](https://www.thehindu.com/news/national/telangana/cyclone-michaung-causes-flight-disruptions-at-hyderabad-airport/article67603629.ece).

#### Compensation for Flight Disruptions:

Passengers may be entitled to compensation or ticket reimbursement in the event of flight delays, cancellations, or overbooking. However, compensation for flight disruptions due to bad weather is subject to certain conditions. Under EU Regulation 261, passengers can usually claim compensation for bad weather-related flight disruptions if the flight took off from a European airport or was operated by a European airline and landed in the European Union [[3]](https://www.flightright.co.uk/your-rights/bad-weather).

#### Conclusion:

Persistent fog and unfavorable weather conditions led to the diversion, delay, and cancellation of numerous flights across the nation. Hyderabad's Rajiv Gandhi International Airport served as a diversion hub for several airlines. Passengers affected by flight disruptions due to bad weather may be eligible for compensation, subject to certain conditions.

title: Maharashtra Speaker’s decision conflicts with SC ruling on factions
summary:
#### Summary of Maharashtra Speaker's Decision and SC Ruling on Factions

The Maharashtra Speaker's decision regarding the "real" Shiv Sena party conflicts with a Supreme Court judgment. The Speaker based their decision on the "legislative majority" held by the faction led by Chief Minister Eknath Shinde, claiming that they were the "real" Shiv Sena. However, a Constitution Bench of the Supreme Court, led by Chief Justice of India D.Y. Chandrachud, directed in a May 2023 judgment that the Speaker must not base their decision solely on which group possesses a majority in the Legislative Assembly. The court emphasized that the determination of the real party goes beyond numbers and includes the structure of leadership outside the legislative assembly. The court also clarified that the strength in numbers of a faction is irrelevant if the legislators are found guilty of defection by splitting the party, and they would be disqualified under the Tenth Schedule (anti-defection law) of the Constitution. The Constitution (Ninety-first Amendment) Act, 2003 deleted the provision of 'split' in Paragraph 3 of the Tenth Schedule, making the defense of a split no longer available to members facing disqualification proceedings [[1]](https://www.thehindu.com/news/national/maharashtra-speakers-decision-conflicts-with-sc-ruling-on-factions/article67741107.ece).

The Supreme Court had set a deadline for the Maharashtra Speaker to decide on disqualification pleas related to the split in the NCP by January 31, 2024, emphasizing the importance of maintaining the sanctity of the Tenth Schedule. The court had also questioned the Speaker's delay in adjudicating the disqualification petitions and urged the Speaker to fulfill their responsibilities in a timely manner [[3]](https://www.thehindu.com/news/national/sc-sets-deadline-for-maharashtra-assembly-speaker-to-decide-on-disqualification-petitions/article67475881.ece) [[6]](https://www.hindustantimes.com/india-news/shiv-sena-disqualification-pleas-rahul-narwekar-eknath-shinde-mlas-supreme-court-101698651340396.html) [[7]](https://indianexpress.com/article/india/sc-sets-december-31-deadline-for-maharashtra-speaker-to-decide-on-disqualification-pleas-against-shinde-faction-9005866/).

title: Last batch of Mizoram Bru refugees permanently settled in Tripura
summary:
The Tripura government has allocated land for the rehabilitation of the last batch of Mizoram Bru refugees, who were granted permanent settlement in Tripura through a Home Ministry-initiated quadripartite agreement signed on January 16, 2020. The agreement aimed to permanently settle a total of 6,959 Bru tribe families comprising 37,136 persons in 12 different locations across four districts in Tripura.

The settlement process has now been completed with the identification and allocation of land for the final group of refugees. The 12th settlement colony has been established in Laugangsom, located in the Santirbazar subdivision in south Tripura district. This colony will accommodate 633 Bru families and will be spread over an area of 30 hectares that was previously unused. Basic amenities such as electricity, drinking water, and other civic facilities are currently being provided at the site.

In addition to land allocation, the refugees are receiving monthly rations, household items, and a stipend as per the quadripartite agreement signed by the Ministry of Home Affairs (MHA) and the governments of Tripura and Mizoram with the representatives of the Bru refugees. The MHA has allocated \u20b9661 crore for the implementation of this agreement.

It is worth noting that the Bru refugees fled ethnic tensions in Mizoram in October 1997 and have been living in sub-human conditions in tents in Tripura. The quadripartite agreement aims to provide a permanent solution to their displacement and improve their living conditions [[5]](https://www.thehindu.com/news/national/other-states/displaced-bru-tribals-from-mizoram-to-permanently-settle-in-tripura/article61643819.ece).

Overall, the Tripura government has allocated land for the final group of Mizoram Bru refugees, completing the settlement process as per the quadripartite agreement. The refugees are receiving basic amenities, monthly support, and other provisions to facilitate their permanent settlement in Tripura [[1]](https://www.thehindu.com/news/national/other-states/last-batch-of-mizoram-bru-refugees-permanently-settled-in-tripura/article67740680.ece).

title: Days after infant’s death, M.P. CM seeks suggestions to curb stray dog menace

#### Summary of the Incident

On January 10, a tragic incident occurred in Bhopal, Madhya Pradesh, where a seven-month-old boy was mauled to death by a pack of stray dogs in the Ayodhya Nagar area. The incident was captured in a viral video, showing the gruesome attack that resulted in the severing of the child's arm. The child's family, who are laborers from Guna district, held the last rites on Wednesday itself. Following this tragic event, the Chief Minister sought suggestions from the public to address the issue of stray dog attacks and prevent similar incidents in the future [[1]](https://www.indiatoday.in/india/madhya-pradesh/story/madhya-pradesh-stray-dog-attack-infant-death-chief-minister-mohan-yadav-2488554-2024-01-14).

In response to the incident, the Bhopal Municipal Corporation caught eight stray dogs from Ayodhya Nagar, and the Collector directed a campaign to catch such animals. Additionally, the Chief Minister directed officials to seek suggestions from the people to take appropriate measures to prevent similar incidents. The body of the child was exhumed and sent for post-mortem examination on Saturday. The Ayodhya Nagar inspector, Mahesh Nilhare, reported that the child's mother had placed him on the ground to work nearby when the pack of dogs attacked him. The police and administration were alerted to the incident after the video went viral on social media [[1]](https://www.indiatoday.in/india/madhya-pradesh/story/madhya-pradesh-stray-dog-attack-infant-death-chief-minister-mohan-yadav-2488554-2024-01-14) [[4]](https://indianexpress.com/article/india/infant-mauled-to-death-by-dogs-mp-cm-seeks-peoples-suggestions-to-prevent-such-incidents-9108815/) [[7]](https://www.telegraphindia.com/feeds/india/seven-month-old-boy-mauled-to-death-by-stray-dogs-in-madhya-pradeshs-bhopal/cid/1993503).

#### Conclusion

The tragic incident of the seven-month-old boy being mauled to death by stray dogs in Bhopal has prompted the Chief Minister to take immediate action, including providing financial assistance to the family and seeking suggestions from the public to prevent similar incidents. The local authorities have also taken steps to catch stray dogs in the area and investigate the circumstances surrounding the attack.

title: Nominations invited for first-ever 'Rashtriya Vigyan Puraskar'
summary:
#### Summary of Rashtriya Vigyan Puraskar

The government has called for nominations for the Rashtriya Vigyan Puraskar, the first-ever national science award, which aims to recognize notable and inspiring contributions made by scientists, technologists, and innovators individually or in teams across various fields of science, technology, and technology-led innovation. The awards were instituted last year after scrapping more than 300 awards given by different institutions. The Rashtriya Vigyan Puraskar is set to be one of the highest recognitions in the field of science, technology, and innovation in India [[1]](https://www.indiatoday.in/science/story/rashtriya-vigyan-puraskar-all-you-need-to-know-about-the-new-science-awards-2438688-2023-09-21).

#### Award Categories and Criteria
The awards will be given across four categories: Vigyan Ratna (VR), Vigyan Shri (VS), Vigyan Yuva: Shanti Swarup Bhatnagar (VY-SSB), and Vigyan Team (VT). A total of 56 awards will be given in thirteen domains, including physics, chemistry, biological sciences, mathematics and computer science, earth science, medicine, engineering sciences, agricultural science, environmental science, technology and innovation, atomic energy, space science and technology. The awards will not be conferred posthumously, except in "highly deserving cases" [[3]](https://currentaffairs.adda247.com/government-comes-out-with-a-new-set-of-national-awards-known-as-rashtriya-vigyan-puraskar/).

#### Eligibility and Recognition
The Rashtriya Vigyan Puraskar is open to scientists, technologists, and innovators working in various sectors, including government and private organizations. Individuals of Indian origin residing abroad who have significantly benefited Indian communities or society as a whole are also eligible for these prestigious awards. The awards aim to recognize distinguished contributions through path-breaking research, innovation, or discovery in any field of science, technology, or technology-led innovation. Gender parity is also a crucial aspect, ensuring representation from each field [[3]](https://currentaffairs.adda247.com/government-comes-out-with-a-new-set-of-national-awards-known-as-rashtriya-vigyan-puraskar/).

#### Timeline and Announcement
The last date for filing nominations is February 28, and the awards will be announced on May 11, National Technology Day. The awards will be conferred on August 23, National Space Day, to commemorate Chandrayaan-3 mission's soft landing on the moon.

#### Conclusion
The Rashtriya Vigyan Puraskar is a significant initiative by the government to recognize and encourage exceptional contributions in the field of science, technology, and innovation in India. It encompasses a wide range of scientific and technological domains and aims to honor both lifetime achievements and distinguished contributions by young scientists and teams.

title: BDL-made Akash missile can strike four aerial targets simultaneously
summary:
#### Summary:

India has achieved a significant milestone by demonstrating the capability of engaging four aerial targets simultaneously at 25 km ranges using the 'Akash' missile, marking a major achievement in the field of defense technology. The Akash missile, developed by the Defence Research and Development Organisation (DRDO) and produced by Bharat Dynamics Limited (BDL), is a medium-range mobile surface-to-air missile system with the ability to protect vulnerable areas and points from air attacks. The recent firing of the Akash missile by the Indian Air Force (IAF) showcased its capability to engage multiple targets simultaneously, further solidifying its position as a key asset in India's defense arsenal [[1]](https://www.thehindu.com/news/national/telangana/bdl-made-akash-missile-can-strike-four-aerial-targets-simultaneously/article67740668.ece).

#### Akash Missile Capabilities:
- The Akash missile system is designed to protect vulnerable areas and points from air attacks, with the ability to simultaneously engage multiple targets in group mode or autonomous mode. It also features built-in Electronic Counter-Counter Measures (ECCM) capabilities [[4]](https://www.drdo.gov.in/akash).
- The missile is capable of striking enemy aerial targets such as fighter jets, drones, cruise missiles, air-to-surface missiles, and ballistic missiles from a distance of 30 km. It can fly at a speed of up to Mach 2.5 (nearly 860 meters per second) at a maximum height of 18 km [[10]](https://economictimes.indiatimes.com/news/defence/akash-missile-all-about-indias-first-home-made-supersonic-missile/articleshow/72119996.cms).

#### Manufacturing and Development:
- The Akash missiles have been manufactured by BDL at its Kanchanbagh facility, emphasizing the focus on 'Make in India' with maximum indigenous content.
- BDL's manufacturing capability has been augmented to meet both domestic and international demands of Astra missiles, positioning it among a select few companies globally with the capability to manufacture state-of-the-art air-to-air missiles.

#### Minister's Visit and Future Outlook:
- Union Minister of State for Defence Ajay Bhatt visited BDL and DRDO establishments, where he congratulated BDL for their efforts in realizing the production of the indigenously developed missile, in line with the Centre\u2019s Atmanirbhar policy. He also emphasized the need to tap into the knowledge and infrastructure base of DRDO for the establishment of a self-reliant defense industrial ecosystem in India.
- The Minister highlighted the need for DRDO to emerge as a world leader in exporting weapon systems to other nations, emphasizing that defense encompasses not only land, sea, and skies but also space, cyber, economic, and social space.

This recent development showcases India's advancements in defense technology and its commitment to self-reliance in defense manufacturing.

title: Release water from Ramanpad to protect standing crops: Jupally
summary:
Minister for Excise and Culture Jupally Krishna Rao has instructed the irrigation authorities to release water from the Ramanpad project to protect the standing Kharif paddy crops. The Minister visited the Ramanpad project after a group of farmers from the Jurala project ayacut met him and explained the need for water for one wetting to ensure a good harvest. The water from the Jurala Left Canal-Ramanpad-Gopaldinne reservoir will serve the ayacut in several mandals, including Amarachinta, Atmakur, Madanapuram, Kothakota, Pebbair, Srirangapuram, Veepanagandla, and Chinnambavi [[1]](https://www.thehindu.com/news/national/telangana/release-water-from-ramanpad-to-protect-standing-crops-jupally/article67741133.ece).

#### Water Availability and Distribution
The Minister inquired with the irrigation officials about the availability of water to ensure one wetting for the Kharif crop and meet the drinking water needs in the coming summer season. The officials informed him that water drawn from Jurala through the Bhima Lift Irrigation Project could be given to the ayacut in Kothakota, Srirangapuram, Veepanagandla, Chinnampalli, and Pentlapalli mandals.

#### Importance of Water Resources
Water is an essential resource for the sustenance of life and the development of the economy. Therefore, the development, conservation, and management of water resources are crucial [[3]](https://jalshakti-dowr.gov.in).

In summary, Minister Jupally Krishna Rao has instructed the irrigation authorities to release water from the Ramanpad project to protect the standing Kharif paddy crops. The water will be distributed to various mandals to ensure a good harvest and meet the drinking water needs in the coming summer season [[1]](https://www.thehindu.com/news/national/telangana/release-water-from-ramanpad-to-protect-standing-crops-jupally/article67741133.ece).

title: Pottela pandelu, yedla pandelu, rangoli competitions mark Sankranti festivities in villages in Andhra Pradesh
summary:
#### Summary of Sankranti Festivities in Andhra Pradesh

The Sankranti festivities in Andhra Pradesh were marked by palpable excitement in villages, with homes adorned with spectacular rangolis and the air filled with the aroma of traditional sweets. The celebrations began with farmers lighting bhogi fires and offering prayers for good rains. Additionally, pujas were performed for tractors, bullock carts, and other agricultural equipment in the fields. Women prepared traditional sweets such as pootarekulu, ariselu, sunnundalu, and payasam to celebrate Bhogi on Day 1 of Sankranti, also known as the harvest festival. Various competitions and events, including bullock cart competitions, 'banda lagudu', 'pottela pandelu', 'yedla pandelu', kite festival, rangoli contests, and traditional dress competitions, were organized in towns and villages. The police department also organized kabaddi, kho-kho, shuttle, volleyball, and other competitions for the youth in villages in Krishna district. The festival was celebrated with great enthusiasm and participation from residents and farmers from various districts [[1]](https://www.thehindu.com/news/national/andhra-pradesh/pottela-pandelu-yedla-pandelu-rangoli-competitions-mark-sankranti-festivities-in-villages-in-andhra-pradesh/article67741496.ece).

#### Significance of Sankranti in Andhra Pradesh
Sankranti is a major festival in both the Telugu states, with Andhra Pradesh celebrating its significance more prominently. The festival is particularly significant in the coastal districts of Andhra Pradesh, where agriculture is the predominant activity. The three-day harvest festival begins with Bhogi and ends with Kanuma, with the main festival celebrated on the second day, known as Sankranti. On Bhogi, the first day of the festival, people burn all negativity by symbolically lighting a bonfire and discarding old and unused items. The festival is a time of celebration for the farming community, marked by good harvest and various traditional rituals and activities [[3]](https://www.deccanchronicle.com/nation/current-affairs/070124/when-is-bhogi-and-sankranthi-2024-date-puja-time.html).

#### Conclusion
The Sankranti festivities in Andhra Pradesh were a vibrant celebration of tradition, agriculture, and community, with a wide range of activities and competitions organized to mark the occasion. The festival holds great significance in the coastal districts of Andhra Pradesh, where agriculture plays a central role in the community's livelihood and culture.

title: CPI(M) in Kerala counters nepotism charges by BJP, Congress
summary:
The Communist Party of India (Marxist) [CPI(M)] in Kerala has responded to allegations of nepotism made by the Congress and the Bharatiya Janata Party (BJP). The CPI(M) defended the government against corruption allegations and accused the Congress of supporting a political witch-hunt [[1]](https://www.thehindu.com/news/national/kerala/cpim-counters-nepotism-charges-by-bjp-cong/article67741390.ece). The controversy revolves around the company affairs of Chief Minister Pinarayi Vijayan's daughter, T. Veena, and her now defunct IT consultancy firm. The Congress and BJP have attempted to portray the monthly payments received by Veena's firm from a Kochi-based mining company as an example of profiting from proximity to power The high-profile inquiry into the matter originated from an Income Tax tribunal decision that the mining firm could not legitimately claim an input tax credit for various payments, including those made to Veena's firm and politicians from different parties The CPI(M) criticized the tribunal's conclusion that Veena's firm had provided no tangible IT services to the mining company without notifying or hearing her [[1]](https://www.thehindu.com/news/national/kerala/cpim-counters-nepotism-charges-by-bjp-cong/article67741390.ece). The BJP also alleged that Congress and Indian Union Muslim League (IUML) leaders had received significant payments from the mining firm in exchange for political protection for its environmentally hazardous quarrying operations.

The CPI(M) defended the government by stating that the civil inquiry into the IT firm's transactions lost its sensational value if the Chief Minister was subtracted from the equation [[1]](https://www.thehindu.com/news/national/kerala/cpim-counters-nepotism-charges-by-bjp-cong/article67741390.ece). The party accused the Congress in Kerala of becoming an ideological echo chamber of the BJP by supporting the Centre's political witch-hunt against Chief Minister Vijayan [[1]](https://www.thehindu.com/news/national/kerala/cpim-counters-nepotism-charges-by-bjp-cong/article67741390.ece). The BJP sought to seize the moral high ground in the controversy by alleging that Congress and IUML leaders had also received large payments from the mining firm [[1]](https://www.thehindu.com/news/national/kerala/cpim-counters-nepotism-charges-by-bjp-cong/article67741390.ece).

title: CPI(M) disavows personality cult politics and says MT’s speech was not targetted at CM
summary:
#### Summary of M.V. Govindan's Statements

M.V. Govindan, the State secretary of CPI(M), has refuted claims of a personality cult surrounding Chief Minister Pinarayi Vijayan within the government and the party. He accused the right-wing corporate media of perpetuating this falsehood to influence public opinion against the government and the party. Govindan highlighted that the media misinterpreted Jnanpith laureate M.T. Vasudevan Nair's speech at the Kerala Literary Festival, where Nair actually spoke against strongmen rule, centralization of authority, and personality cults, without targeting any specific individual. Govindan emphasized that the media's misrepresentation reflects a deep-seated animosity towards the proletarian working-class politics pursued by the CPI(M) [[1]](https://www.thehindu.com/news/national/kerala/cpim-disavows-personality-cult-politics-and-says-mts-speech-was-not-targetted-at-cm/article67741452.ece).

#### M.V. Govindan's Defense and Critique
Govindan defended his comparison of Chief Minister Pinarayi Vijayan to the Sun, stating that it symbolized Vijayan's unassailable integrity and aversion to condoning or abetting any wrongdoing. He clarified that M.T. Vasudevan Nair's speech merely reiterated a caution against democracies backsliding into autocracies via the ballot, without specifically targeting Kerala. Govindan attributed the misinterpretation of Nair's speech to the fear of bourgeois and capitalist forces towards the proletariat, with journalists being portrayed as instruments of their employers. He emphasized that the party empathizes with journalists as fellow workers [[1]](https://www.thehindu.com/news/national/kerala/cpim-disavows-personality-cult-politics-and-says-mts-speech-was-not-targetted-at-cm/article67741452.ece).

#### Additional Context
M.V. Govindan's election as the State secretary of CPI(M) has sparked speculation about a possible Cabinet reshuffle. He is a prominent figure within the party, having previously held the post of secretary of the party district committees in Kannur and Thrissur [[2]](https://www.onmanorama.com/news/kerala/2021/05/19/mv-govindan-profile-pinarayi-government.html)(https://www.thehindu.com/news/national/kerala/mv-govindan-is-cpim-state-secretary/article65822550.ece)[[4]]. Additionally, there have been instances where Govindan has been vocal about the attempts by central agencies to target Kerala CM Pinarayi Vijayan, asserting that such actions would not affect the government or the party [[6]](https://www.hindustantimes.com/india-news/central-agencies-trying-to-target-kerala-cm-cpi-m-state-secretary-101676820525634.html).

This summary provides an overview of M.V. Govindan's statements and the context surrounding his defense against the insinuation of a personality cult revolving around Chief Minister Pinarayi Vijayan.

title: WeLead to Credible India: Indian lounges dominate World Economic Forum in Davos
summary:

These lounges showcase Indian leadership, technology, and culture [[1]](https://www.thehindu.com/news/national/welead-to-credible-india-indian-lounges-dominate-davos-promenade/article67742504.ece). title: BJP leaders clean premises of temples
summary:
Prominent BJP leaders in Karnataka participated in a temple cleaning drive in response to Prime Minister Narendra Modi's call to clean the premises of temples ahead of the inauguration of the Ram Mandir in Ayodhya. BJP State president B.Y. Vijayendra cleaned the Huchhurayaswamy temple in Shikaripur, while former Deputy Chief Minister C.N. Ashwath Narayan and State general secretaries P. Rajeev and Preetham Gowda participated in cleaning the Kodandarama Temple in Bengaluru. Leader of the Opposition in the Assembly R. Ashok took part in the cleaning of the Ganesha temple in Jayanagar, Bengaluru.

The temple cleaning drive is part of the 'Swach Mandir' Abhiyan, which was launched across the country ahead of the consecration of the Ram Mandir on January 22 in Ayodhya [[4]](https://www.republicworld.com/india/ram-mandir-inauguration-pm-modi-yogi-adityanth-jp-nadda-pushkar-singh-dhami-others-clean-temples-with-mop-watch/). Overall, the temple cleaning drive in Karnataka by prominent BJP leaders is a response to PM Modi's call and is part of a larger nationwide campaign to promote cleanliness in temples ahead of the inauguration of the Ram Mandir in Ayodhya [[3]](https://news.abplive.com/states/up-uk/ram-mandir-pran-pratishtha-swachhata-abhiyan-bjp-leaders-clean-temples-pm-narendra-modi-ram-mandir-inauguration-1656453) [[4]](https://www.republicworld.com/india/ram-mandir-inauguration-pm-modi-yogi-adityanth-jp-nadda-pushkar-singh-dhami-others-clean-temples-with-mop-watch/).

In summary, President Droupadi Murmu will visit Meghalaya and Assam from January 15 to 17. During her visit, she will inaugurate the Meghalaya Games, address self-help groups, lay foundation stones, and attend the golden jubilee celebrations of the Karbi Youth Festival in Assam.

title: Late soldier’s wife fights an arduous battle for pension
summary:
#### Summary of "Late Soldier\u2019s Wife Fights an Arduous Battle for Pension"

D. Ramu, an Army Naik, was married to Anuradha and received pension until his death in April 2010. After his death, a petition was received from D. Padma claiming to be his widow and seeking family pension. It was revealed that Ramu had married Padma in 2003, years after Anuradha allegedly deserted him, without divorcing Anuradha. The situation was further complicated when Ramu's sister posed as his first wife, Anuradha, during his discharge from service. This led to a lengthy legal battle, culminating in a decision by the Armed Forces Tribunal to recognize Padma's claim for pension due to her sustained cohabitation with Ramu, despite the marriage being void. However, the tribunal restricted the pension arrears to three years prior to the date of the original application.

The case involved complex legal and personal issues, ultimately resulting in a decision to grant pension to Padma based on her sustained cohabitation with Ramu, despite the void marriage. The tribunal's decision was in line with principles laid down by the Supreme Court, but the pension arrears were restricted to three years prior to the date of the original application.

title: BJP leaders take part in temple cleaning drive across the country

title: Urdu poet Munawwar Rana passes away at 71
summary:
Renowned poet Munawwar Rana passed away at the Sanjay Gandhi Post Graduate Institute of Medical Sciences in Lucknow on January 14, 2024, at the age of 71. He had been suffering from throat cancer for a long time [[1]](https://www.thehindu.com/news/national/urdu-poet-munawwar-rana-passes-away-at-71/article67741720.ece) [[2]](https://www.news18.com/india/poet-munawwar-rana-dies-at-71-8740341.html) [[5]](https://www.theweek.in/news/india/2024/01/15/renowned-poet-munawwar-rana-dies-at-age-71.html) [[9]](https://news.abplive.com/news/india/renowned-urdu-poet-munawwar-rana-passes-away-at-71-1656597) [[10]](https://news.abplive.com/web-stories/munawwar-rana-death-renowned-poet-known-for-maa-poem-dies-at-71-1656600). Mr. Rana's daughter, Sumaiya Rana, confirmed his passing and stated that he will be laid to rest on January 15 [[1]](https://www.thehindu.com/news/national/urdu-poet-munawwar-rana-passes-away-at-71/article67741720.ece). He is survived by his wife, four daughters, and a son [[1]](https://www.thehindu.com/news/national/urdu-poet-munawwar-rana-passes-away-at-71/article67741720.ece).

Munawwar Rana was born in 1952 in Rae Bareli and was awarded the Gyanpeeth Award in 2014. His use of simple words in his poems made his works popular among the common people. One of his most famous works is the poem "Maa," which holds a special place in the world of Urdu literature.

The news of Munawwar Rana's demise has been met with condolences from various individuals, including Samajwadi Party president Akhilesh Yadav, who shared a couplet from Rana's poem and expressed his heartfelt tribute.

In summary, renowned poet Munawwar Rana passed away at the age of 71 due to throat cancer. He was known for his popular works in Urdu literature, including the poem "Maa." His passing has been mourned by many, including political figures [[1]](https://www.thehindu.com/news/national/urdu-poet-munawwar-rana-passes-away-at-71/article67741720.ece)

title: Rising sea, shrinking sands erode flair of the famed Ganga Sagar Mela
summary:
#### Summary:

The Ganga Sagar Mela, an annual religious congregation held on Sagar Island in West Bengal, is facing challenges due to rising sea levels and erosion of the beach in front of the Kapil Muni temple. The West Bengal government is seeking 'National Fair' status for the event, but the erosion has become an eyesore. The administration has put up warning signs and diverted pilgrims to other beaches on the island for the holy dip. The government has installed tetrapods to arrest erosion, but the impact will only be known after the monsoon. The construction on the island has violated coastal regulation zones, and experts attribute the erosion to human interventions and the lack of sediment influx from the Ganga Meghna Brahmaputra river system. The rising sea level has also brought the water closer to the Kapil Muni temple, and earlier temples of Kapil Muni have gone under the sea. The West Bengal government has spent about \u20b925 crore for dredging the Sagar Island, which is about 10% of the estimated budget of the Ganga Sagar Mela.

title: Breaking ground: Women commandos take on Maoist stronghold
summary:
#### Summary:

A group of 11 women police officers from the Maharashtra police have been deployed at a critical outpost in the Gadchiroli district of India. These women, informally called commandos, have undergone intensive training in jungle warfare and weaponry. They are positioned at a strategic intersection along the Red Corridor, directly facing the Maoist headquarters in the Dandakaranya forest. The outpost, protected by a 10-feet compound wall and MAC barriers, plays a vital role in launching anti-guerrilla operations and curbing the movement of insurgents. The women commandos are part of a 200-strong security force and are determined to flush out the insurgents from the region. The outpost is the first of its kind to be established before becoming stable, and it is expected to bring significant transformation to the lives of the people in the surrounding villages. The deployment of women officers at this outpost is seen as a groundbreaking move in the left-wing extremism (LWE) area of India [[1]](https://www.thehindu.com/news/national/breaking-ground-women-commandos-take-on-maoist-stronghold/article67740633.ece) [[2]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Naxalite\u2013Maoist_insurgency).

#### Women Commandos in Maoist Stronghold:
The women commandos stationed at the outpost in the Gadchiroli district are part of a 200-strong security force. They have undergone intensive training in jungle warfare and weaponry and are informally called commandos. These women are familiar with the treacherous terrain and intricacies of the local language, making them well-equipped to flush out the insurgents from the region. They are passionate about their job and are proud to be part of the elite and historic team. Despite facing challenges and potential danger, they remain vigilant and committed to their duty [[1]](https://www.thehindu.com/news/national/breaking-ground-women-commandos-take-on-maoist-stronghold/article67740633.ece).

#### Strategic Role of the Outpost:
The outpost in Gadchiroli district plays a strategic role in launching anti-guerrilla operations and quelling the movement of insurgents. It is positioned at the gateway to the Maoist headquarters, which strikes fear into the Maoists as it plugs their transit route to the Maharashtra-Madhya Pradesh-Chhattisgarh (MMC) zone. Before the establishment of this outpost, there was a significant security vacuum on the border, as the area was completely under Maoist control. The outpost is protected by a 10-feet compound wall, MAC barriers, and other security measures. It is the first time women officers have been deployed before an outpost became stable, highlighting their key role in this groundbreaking initiative [[1]](https://www.thehindu.com/news/national/breaking-ground-women-commandos-take-on-maoist-stronghold/article67740633.ece).

#### Challenges and Security Measures:
The outpost in the Gadchiroli district is susceptible to attacks due to the historical dominance of Maoists in the area. The security forces stationed there have to remain vigilant at all times and leave no security lapse, as any lapse could prove fatal. To enhance security, the outpost has implemented Defencell MAC barriers, a system used by U.S. troops in Afghanistan and Iraq to protect their compounds. With a 10-feet compound wall and MAC barriers, the outpost has two-layer solid protection. The implementation of these security measures aims to ensure the safety of the commandos and the success of their mission [[1]](https://www.thehindu.com/news/national/breaking-ground-women-commandos-take-on-maoist-stronghold/article67740633.ece).

#### Impact on the Region:
The establishment of the outpost in the Gadchiroli district has brought significant transformation to the lives of over 5,000 people in the 13 surrounding villages. The presence of the outpost and its commandos has provided security and stability to the region. Development initiatives, such as the construction of roads and cell towers, are underway, further improving the lives of the local population. The outpost has also brought civil administration to an area that was previously known as the "Liberated Zone." The pioneering team of women commandos has played a crucial role in this transformation [[1]](https://www.thehindu.com/news/national/breaking-ground-women-commandos-take-on-maoist-stronghold/article67740633.ece).

#### Conclusion:
The deployment of women commandos at the critical outpost in the Gadchiroli district is a groundbreaking move in the fight against left-wing extremism in India. These highly trained officers are positioned strategically to combat Maoist insurgents and disrupt their activities in the region. The outpost plays a vital role in launching anti-guerrilla operations and bringing stability and development to the surrounding villages. The women commandos, along with the security forces, are determined to ensure the safety and well-being of the local population and flush out the insurgents from the area [[1]](https://www.thehindu.com/news/national/breaking-ground-women-commandos-take-on-maoist-stronghold/article67740633.ece)

title: Saplings of native trees replace invasive species in Anamalai Tiger Reserve’s core areas
summary:
The Forest Department has undertaken a mass removal of invasive species in the Ulandy range within the core area of the Anamalai Tiger Reserve (ATR). This initiative aims to restore degraded forest lands by planting saplings of native trees after clearing invasive plants. In the current financial year, 90 hectares of forest lands in the Ulandy range alone have been cleared of invasive plants and native tree saplings have been planted [[1]](https://www.thehindu.com/news/national/tamil-nadu/saplings-of-native-trees-replace-invasive-species-in-anamalai-tiger-reserves-core-areas/article67740719.ece).

The Restoration of Degraded Forests Landscape Project, with financial assistance from the National Bank for Agriculture and Rural Development (NABARD), is being implemented to carry out these restoration works in the core areas of the ATR. The project was launched by the Tamil Nadu government in 2022 to remove invasive plants and enhance green cover in forest lands. The Forest Department, in consultation with experts and biologists, identified the lands for restoration in the ATR [[2]](https://timesofindia.indiatimes.com/city/coimbatore/native-species-planting-in-ulandy-to-restore-reserve-forest/articleshow/106849674.cms).

One specific forest patch in the Ulandy range, which previously had large areas of bamboo, is also being restored. After a forest fire in 2015, invasive species such as Lantana camara and Eupatorium took over the fertile ground. The Forest Department engaged people from the ATR's tribal settlements to remove the invasive plants and plant saplings of native trees, including Aegle marmelos (Vilvam), Syzygium cumini (Jamun), Pterocarpus marsupium (Vengai), and bamboo seedlings [[1]](https://www.thehindu.com/news/national/tamil-nadu/saplings-of-native-trees-replace-invasive-species-in-anamalai-tiger-reserves-core-areas/article67740719.ece).

In total, 9,000 saplings have been planted on 90 hectares of forest lands in the Ulandy range so far. The government aims to restore 33,290 hectares of degraded forest lands in Tamil Nadu within five years through this project, for which NABARD has provided a loan of \u20b9457 crore. The restoration efforts in the ATR cover a total of 270 hectares of land across all forest ranges [[1]](https://www.thehindu.com/news/national/tamil-nadu/saplings-of-native-trees-replace-invasive-species-in-anamalai-tiger-reserves-core-areas/article67740719.ece).

Invasive species pose a significant threat to native wildlife and ecosystems. They can cause economic and environmental harm to the areas they invade. In the case of the Anamalai Tiger Reserve, the Forest Department's efforts to remove invasive species and restore native trees contribute to the conservation and restoration of the reserve's biodiversity and habitat [[3]](https://www.nwf.org/Educational-Resources/Wildlife-Guide/Threats-to-Wildlife/Invasive-Species).

Overall, the Forest Department's mass removal of invasive species and the subsequent planting of native tree saplings in the Ulandy range of the Anamalai Tiger Reserve is part of a larger project aimed at restoring degraded forest lands in Tamil Nadu. This initiative not only helps combat the threat of invasive species but also contributes to the conservation of native wildlife and the enhancement of green cover in the region [[1]](https://www.thehindu.com/news/national/tamil-nadu/saplings-of-native-trees-replace-invasive-species-in-anamalai-tiger-reserves-core-areas/article67740719.ece) [[2]](https://timesofindia.indiatimes.com/city/coimbatore/native-species-planting-in-ulandy-to-restore-reserve-forest/articleshow/106849674.cms).

title: Telangana fighting surge in spurious drug trade; doctors sound alarm
summary:
#### Summary:

Enforcement agencies in Telangana, India, have recently conducted raids to uncover the business of spurious drugs. The Drugs Control Administration (DCA) has targeted 10 facilities, resulting in the confiscation of nearly 1,171 kg of counterfeit medications worth \u20b99.76 crore. Spurious drugs, also known as counterfeit drugs, are deceitfully manufactured medicines designed to mimic reputable products. These fraudulent medications can have severe health implications and may even bear the details of non-existent manufacturers. Medical experts warn that the consumption of such illicit drugs poses a significant health risk, as they fail to address medical conditions and can lead to disastrous consequences over time. The recent raids have revealed a disturbing trend, with fake medicines falsely labeled under the names of reputable companies [[1]](https://www.thehindu.com/news/national/telangana/telangana-fighting-surge-in-spurious-drug-trade-doctors-sound-alarm/article67740688.ece).

#### Impact on Trust and Health:
Kiran Madala, the Scientific Committee convenor of the Indian Medical Association-Telangana State, highlights the potential impact of spurious drugs on trust in medicines, healthcare providers, and health systems. Lookalike drugs may appear genuine until closely examined, revealing poor standards that can harm one's health upon inspection. The prolonged consumption of counterfeit drugs can have serious implications for vital organs like the kidneys and liver, potentially leading to fatal outcomes due to impurities present in illicit substances. Substandard medicines may not have an immediate negative impact, but the unpredictable nature of fake drugs, where consumers are unaware of the actual content, poses a significant health risk.

#### Loopholes in Drug Monitoring Standards:
There is a critical loophole in the drug monitoring system at the state level. While the preparation of a new drug requires approval from the Central government, state drug control bodies are often understaffed and lack a robust monitoring system. This provides an entry point for companies to introduce spurious drugs into the market without proper scrutiny. The recent raids by the DCA officials have exposed the presence of fake medicines falsely labeled under the names of reputable companies such as Sun Pharma, Glenmark Pharma, Aristo Pharmaceuticals, and Torrent Pharma [[1]](https://www.thehindu.com/news/national/telangana/telangana-fighting-surge-in-spurious-drug-trade-doctors-sound-alarm/article67740688.ece).

In conclusion, the recent raids conducted by the Drugs Control Administration in Telangana have uncovered the business of spurious drugs. These counterfeit medications pose a severe threat to health and can have disastrous consequences for patients. Medical experts emphasize the need for stricter monitoring and regulation to combat the proliferation of spurious drugs and protect public health

summary:
In a session discussing the 'Hundred Years of Turkish Republic' at the Kerala Literature Festival, A.K. Pasha, the Director of Gulf Studies Programme at Jawaharlal Nehru University, highlighted the influence of Turkey's conversion from an Islamic past into a secular republic on Indian leaders during the framing of the Constitution. Pasha noted that Turkey's secular attitude, embraced by Turks regardless of their religious backgrounds, served as an inspiration for India. The common trait of secularism formed a bond between the two countries. 

Cemil Kutluturk, from the History of Religions Department at Ankara University, added that Turkey also followed the Indian concept of 'Vasudhaiva Kutumbakam,' though it was rephrased as 'Peace to All.' Kutluturk elaborated on the cultural influence resulting from marriages between Turkish royalty and the Hyderabadi family. 

Pasha further explained India's contribution to the Turkish liberation movement and the convergence of intentions between the people of both countries after World War I. He also mentioned the support of the Indian Khilafat movement for the Turkish liberation movement. The session was moderated by the Turkish Ambassador to India, Firat Sunel.

title: Consecration of Ram temple is a political gimmick, says T.R. Baalu
summary:
#### Summary of DMK's Criticism of the Consecration of Ram Temple at Ayodhya

The DMK has launched a scathing attack on the consecration of the Ram temple at Ayodhya, alleging that the BJP government at the Centre had made a gimmick of consecrating an incomplete temple in view of the upcoming Lok Sabha election. DMK Parliamentary Party leader T.R. Baalu criticized the BJP government for using the consecration of the Ram temple as a political gimmick ahead of elections. He stated that the BJP government, after "hunting down the people of the country in every way in the last ten years," was now claiming that it had completed the construction of the Ram temple [[1]](https://www.thehindu.com/news/national/tamil-nadu/dmk-consecration-of-ram-temple-is-a-political-gimmick/article67741644.ece).

Baalu emphasized that faith in God is an individual's spiritual quest and right, and using bhakti as a capital for political mobilization and vote-bank politics is against the soul of India and values of the Constitution. He further stated that capitalizing on individuals' faith and right was against democratic norms and spiritual values. Baalu also criticized the BJP government and Prime Minister Narendra Modi for seeking to deceive the people by highlighting the construction and consecration of a temple as an achievement. He expressed that the people of India will reject the BJP government's attempt to convert a spiritual festival into a political festival.

Moreover, Baalu condemned the BJP for using a temple festival for laying the stone for its 'Mother rashtra' and accused the party of continuing its efforts to destroy India's character of unity in diversity. He stated that instead of doing good for the people, the party tries to win through means of deceit. Baalu also highlighted the DMK's commitment to secularism and its dedication to harmonious politics filled with fraternalism. He mentioned that the DMK never took advantage of the ideas of linking politics with bhakti and spiritualism. Additionally, he pointed out that the DMK government led by Chief Minister M.K. Stalin had renovated and performed 'kumbabishekam' for thousands of temples and reclaimed temple properties to the tune of \u20b95,381 crore but never spoke about them on election platforms for the sake of vote bank politics [[1]](https://www.thehindu.com/news/national/tamil-nadu/dmk-consecration-of-ram-temple-is-a-political-gimmick/article67741644.ece).

In conclusion, the DMK's criticism of the consecration of the Ram temple at Ayodhya revolves around the accusation of the BJP government using it as a political gimmick ahead of elections and capitalizing on individuals' faith for political gains, which the DMK views as against the democratic norms and spiritual values of India [[1]](https://www.thehindu.com/news/national/tamil-nadu/dmk-consecration-of-ram-temple-is-a-political-gimmick/article67741644.ece).

title: Periyar University V-C moves Madras High Court to quash FIR registered against him
summary:

Periyar University Vice-Chancellor (V-C) R. Jagannathan has filed a plea to quash an FIR registered against him under the Scheduled Castes and Scheduled Tribes (Prevention of Atrocities) Act, 1989, and the charge of cheating under the Indian Penal Code. The V-C alleges that the FIR was filed with the intention of tarnishing his image and reputation. The plea is scheduled to be heard before Justice N. Anand Venkatesh on January 18, 2024. The V-C denies the charges against him and claims that the university had not invested any funds in the company in question. He also alleges misuse of the SC/ST (PoA) Act and police excess in his case, claiming that the entire case was framed with ulterior motives. The V-C further states that there was some misunderstanding with "political personalities" regarding the appointment of Registrar and the Controller of Examination for Periyar University, and he had followed the rules and regulations in these appointments in accordance with legal procedures.

#### Allegations and Response:
The V-C alleges that the FIR was registered with an ulterior motive to tarnish his image and reputation He denies the charge of swindling university funds and provides details about the establishment of the Periyar University Technology Entrepreneurship Research (PUTER) Foundation, claiming it was a non-profit company established in accordance with a Government Order He also denies the charge of having used cuss words referring to the caste of the complainant and alleges misuse of the SC/ST (PoA) Act The V-C further claims police excess and states that the entire case was framed with ulterior motives He also mentions a misunderstanding with "political personalities" regarding the appointment of Registrar and the Controller of Examination for Periyar University, stating that he had followed the rules and regulations in these appointments in accordance with legal procedures.

#### Hearing and Judge:
The plea to quash the FIR is listed for hearing before Justice N. Anand Venkatesh on January 18, 2024 Justice N. Anand Venkatesh is a sitting Judge of the Madras High Court 

#### Conclusion:
The V-C's plea to quash the FIR is set to be heard, and he has provided detailed responses to the allegations against him, claiming that the case was framed with ulterior motives and denying the charges. The case involves various legal and administrative aspects, and the involvement of Justice N. Anand Venkatesh adds significance to the proceedings.

title: Stalin writes to Jaishankar seeking release of fishermen
summary:
#### Summary:

Tamil Nadu Chief Minister M K Stalin has written a letter to Union Minister for External Affairs S. title: Accused in attack on police personnel arrested
summary:
#### Summary:

The Special Investigation Team (SIT) of the police has apprehended members of a gang involved in multiple cases, including the recent attack on police personnel at Edakkad. The suspects, Abdul Rahim, E.K. Nithin, Naveen alias Boney, and Shahid, were taken into custody from a lodge at Payyannur. The operation was led by Kannur Town inspector Binu Mohan. Abdul Rahim had previously served six months in jail under the Kerala Anti-Social Activities (Prevention) Act (KAAPA), while Naveen and Shahid faced a total of 10 and six cases respectively, including charges under KAAPA. The suspects were implicated in the recent attack on police personnel at Edakkad, where they used beer bottles and weapons, resulting in injuries to a senior civil police officer. The police managed to apprehend the suspects despite their resistance and resorting to violence during the arrest [[1]](https://www.thehindu.com/news/national/kerala/accused-in-attack-on-police-personnel-arrested/article67740318.ece).

#### Additional Information:

The gang members were involved in multiple cases, and their arrest was a breakthrough for the police. The operation took place in Payyanur, where the suspects were confronted by the police and subsequently apprehended. The suspects' history of criminal activities, including previous convictions and charges under the Kerala Anti-Social Activities (Prevention) Act, highlights their involvement in organized crime. The attack on police personnel at Edakkad was a significant incident that led to their identification and subsequent arrest.

title: Colloquium discusses geopolitical implications of Israel-Hamas war
summary:
#### Summary:

A colloquium titled "Palestine: Endless Occupation, Permanent Crisis" was held at the Asian College of Journalism in Chennai. The event focused on the geopolitical implications of the Israel-Hamas war. The speakers discussed various aspects of the conflict, including the challenges to the "Two-state solution" and the role of different countries and international organizations.

Former Indian diplomat Rakesh Sood highlighted how the idea of a Two-state solution has been undermined by right-wing governments in Israel over the past 25 years, with little intervention from the international community [[1]](https://www.thehindu.com/news/national/tamil-nadu/colloquium-discusses-geopolitical-implications-of-israel-hamas-war/article67740453.ece). Professor P.R. Kumaraswamy emphasized the de facto separation among Palestinians and argued that the Two-state solution remains the most realistic and viable option, despite its difficulties [[1]](https://www.thehindu.com/news/national/tamil-nadu/colloquium-discusses-geopolitical-implications-of-israel-hamas-war/article67740453.ece). Air Marshal M. Matheswaran described Israel as a geopolitical outpost of the great powers and criticized the U.S. and the U.K. for their role in the conflict [[1]](https://www.thehindu.com/news/national/tamil-nadu/colloquium-discusses-geopolitical-implications-of-israel-hamas-war/article67740453.ece).

The speakers also discussed the role of the U.S. in the conflict. While there were criticisms of the U.S., Professor Kumaraswamy acknowledged that there is currently no other country capable of taking on the heavy-lifting in resolving the conflict [[1]](https://www.thehindu.com/news/national/tamil-nadu/colloquium-discusses-geopolitical-implications-of-israel-hamas-war/article67740453.ece). The United States' unconditional support for Israel's military operation was contrasted with its response to other conflicts, such as Russia's invasion of Ukraine.

Overall, the colloquium provided a platform for experts to discuss the geopolitical implications of the Israel-Hamas war and the challenges in finding a resolution to the conflict.
